channel.title: Downgrade to windows XP
channel.description:
Yeah I did it over the weekend, really easy so I felt like putting a tut on it.
[b]I WILL NOT TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR ANYTHING THAT HAPPENS TO YOUR COMPUTER!![/b] its not my problem if you jack up your computer and forget to make recoveries. even order recoveries from your manufacturer BEFORE you do this if it makes you feel safe. Don't do it after as it may void your warranty.
[b]BEFORE YOU START[/b] create a set of vista recovery disks, dual layer dvds do the best as they hold the most (8gb I think). I almost had to use them because my computer would spontaneously restart during the second stage of the installation (after the reboot).
1. find an XP disk. I don't do stuff illegally so I just got an XP professional from my uncle. 2. Back up data. I just backed up my documents, pictures and stuff (stuff I'll probably never put back up on my computer) 3. Pop in the disk and reboot from it. 4. It will give you the option to delete partitions. Delete your windows one and do a quick (or full, quick is faster obviously). It gets iffy here when you have linux. Leave your swap partition and your linux partition, grub will need to be reinstalled later. I believe you can do this either with super grub or your linux disk. http://www.supergrubdisk.org/ 5. Let it install. 6. Your computer will then reboot, when it turns on it will say to press any key to boot from the cd, don't press any key. 7. XP will finish installing, prompts will come up for you to enter passwords, users, and whatever. 8. There you will have your windows XP
The glory of this is that you have a completely "new" computer with no start up items, no pre installed junk, or any junk for that matter. I'm using my XP now and it runs better than any vista I've used.

item.title: Downgrade to windows XP
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

blah bah7:

imo its the only microsoft supported virus. it hoards your ram, i have had more bluescreens with vista than any other computer i have had combined, and it has froze the most.

Don’t you ever had Windows 98.

But no point doing this any longer, upgrade to Windows 7 much better.

Read full topic

item.title: Downgrade to windows XP
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

[quote=“FastBawlz, post:11, topic:247884”][quote author=Waffendennis link=topic=326887.msg2572509#msg2572509 date=1228766299]
Nice tutorial, how ever keep in mind that windows XP is a bitch with Quad Core CPU’s.
And it isn’t supporting 4+GB’s op RAM.
[/quote]

Doesn’t 64-bit support 4+GB’s?[/quote]

Technically PAE (physical address extension, now (somewhat?) standard in XP) allows for utilization of full 64 bit memory addressing.

However, in XP only 4GB is allowed to be used due to potential driver issues that would occur when using > 4GB (just a money thing I guess, XP is already on its way out, so they could care less).

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @adamp40 adamp40
item.description:
@adamp40 wrote:

This is just how to install XP… and its not even detailed

Microsoft offer “Downgrade Rights” for XP for like another 6 months anyway. After that they will stop selling the Install CD but there will still be OEM version and if you want XP you have to illeaglly aquire it.

Read full topic

item.title: Downgrade to windows XP
item.dc:creator: @IP-Drowner IP-Drowner
item.description:
@IP-Drowner wrote:

I can tell you now, that i have never had a blue screen with Vista. Never! My video card failed once (over-heated), vista told me it stopped responding and crashed, then Vista tried to restart it. If it couldn’t restart it, it’d use the backup video card until it could restart it. No blue-screen.

Read full topic

item.title: Downgrade to windows XP

item.description:
@blah_bah7 wrote:

Yeah I did it over the weekend, really easy so I felt like putting a tut on it.

I WILL NOT TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR ANYTHING THAT HAPPENS TO YOUR COMPUTER!!
its not my problem if you jack up your computer and forget to make recoveries. even order recoveries from your manufacturer BEFORE you do this if it makes you feel safe. Don’t do it after as it may void your warranty.

BEFORE YOU START create a set of vista recovery disks, dual layer dvds do the best as they hold the most (8gb I think). I almost had to use them because my computer would spontaneously restart during the second stage of the installation (after the reboot).

  1. find an XP disk. I don’t do stuff illegally so I just got an XP professional from my uncle.
  2. Back up data. I just backed up my documents, pictures and stuff (stuff I’ll probably never put back up on my computer)
  3. Pop in the disk and reboot from it.
  4. It will give you the option to delete partitions. Delete your windows one and do a quick (or full, quick is faster obviously). It gets iffy here when you have linux. Leave your swap partition and your linux partition, grub will need to be reinstalled later. I believe you can do this either with super grub or your linux disk. http://www.supergrubdisk.org/
  5. Let it install.
  6. Your computer will then reboot, when it turns on it will say to press any key to boot from the cd, don’t press any key.
  7. XP will finish installing, prompts will come up for you to enter passwords, users, and whatever.
  8. There you will have your windows XP

The glory of this is that you have a completely “new” computer with no start up items, no pre installed junk, or any junk for that matter. I’m using my XP now and it runs better than any vista I’ve used.
